On the level of religious and sectarian affiliation, 41% were Sunnis, 23% Shiites, rest Kaka’is, and none Christians or Chaldeans.<ref>[http://pukmedia.com/EN/EN_Direje.aspx?Jimare=1890 Memorandum to prevent female genital mutilation in Iraq] PUK, Kurdistan (May 2, 2013)</ref> A 2013 report finds FGM prevalence rate of 59% based on clinical examination of about 2000 Iraqi Kurdish women; FGM found were Type I, and 60% of the mutilation were performed to girls in 4–7 year age group.<ref>Yasin et al. (September 2013) {{cite journal | doi = 10.1186/1471-2458-13-809 | volume=13 | title=Female genital mutilation among Iraqi Kurdish women: a cross-sectional study from Erbil city | year=2013 | journal=BMC Public Health | page=809 | author=Yasin Berivan A}}</ref> See [[Asuda]], a Kurdistan NGO. The highest prevalence rates of FGM are in Kirkuk (20%), Sulaymaniyah (54%) and Erbil (58%).
===Jordan=== Residents of [[Arabah|Wadi Araba]] village in southern [[Jordan]] are known to practice FGM. The practice is foreign to the rest of the country, experts speculate that this practise was introduced through descendants of tribes that came from neighbouring [[Gaza Strip|Gaza]] and [[Beer Sheba]].<ref>[http://www.dailystar.com.lb/Culture/Arts/Nov/13/The-Jordanian-town-that-still-circumcises-women.ashx#axzz2g5h5CT28 The Jordanian town that still circumcises women] Rana Sabbagh-Gargour, The Star (Lebanon)</ref><ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/ethics/femalecircumcision/femalecirc_1.shtml Female circumcision/genital cutting] BBC Guide, United Kingdom (2008)</ref>
===Kuwait=== Female genital mutilation is not practiced in Kuwait.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://data.unicef.org/resources/zero-tolerance-female-genital-mutilation |title=Zero Tolerance For Female Genital Mutilation|publisher=unicef.org|date=|accessdate=2018-02-10}}</ref> Few ethnic migrant minorities are believed to perform the procedure outside of public health institutions where they risk injury and infections.
===Oman=== The practice is very prevalent in [[Oman]].<ref name="meforum1">[http://www.meforum.org/1629/is-female-genital-mutilation-an-islamic-problem "Is Female Genital Mutilation an Islamic Problem?"], ''Middle East Quarterly'', accessed 5 February 2011.</ref> A 2013 article by journalist Susan Mubarak describes FGM practice in Oman, and claims the practice is very common in [[Dhofar Governorate|Dhofar]] in the southwest. The author went on to say that a previous article on the topic received both positive feedback for spreading awareness of what some considered a 'horrific tradition', as well as negative feedback from others for 'hanging Dhofar’s dirty washing for the world to see and criticising a practice that they believe is purely Islamic,' commenting that she 'paid little attention to these criticisms because I know the practice is harmful and primitive', and 'our religion neither encourages the practice nor condemns it.'<ref name="muscatdaily.com"/>
According to a small survey by human rights activist and statistician Habiba Al Hinai conducted in October 2013 and published in January 2014, 78% of 100 women interviewed living in the capital city of [[Muscat]] had undergone FGM. These women came from all parts of the country, each region showing a very high prevalence, and even though fewer women from Muscat itself had undergone FGM, they were still in the majority. Her findings contradicted the common belief that FGM was only widespread in the south.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wluml.org/news/new-study-oman-shows-high-prevalence-fgm-all-over-country |title=New study in Oman shows high prevalence of FGM all over the country | Women Reclaiming and Redefining Cultures |publisher=Wluml.org |date=22 January 2014 |accessdate=6 August 2018}}</ref> Type I is mostly performed in southern Oman and typically performed within a few weeks of a girl's birth, while Type IV is observed in other parts of northern Oman.<ref>[http://www.theweek.co.om/printCon.aspx?Cval=6181 FOCUS ON FGM] Victoria Cuthbert, The Week (Oman), (April 25, 2012)</ref>
FGM otherwise is not practice in Oman neither is considered prominent by the World Health Organization.{{Citation needed|date=August 2018}}
===Palestine=== {{Expand section|date=November 2014}} Female genital mutilation is present in [[State of Palestine|Palestine]].<ref name="unfpa1"/>
===Qatar=== {{Expand section|date=November 2014}} Female genital mutilation is present in [[Qatar]].<ref name="gulfnews.com">[http://gulfnews.com/opinions/columnists/female-genital-mutilation-a-brutal-violation-of-rights-1.1036052 Female genital mutilation: a brutal violation of rights] Asma Malik, Gulf News (June 15, 2012)</ref><ref name="irinnews.org"/>
===Saudi Arabia=== Female genital mutilation is present in [[Saudi Arabia]].<ref name=Birch/><ref name="fgmnetwork.org"/> FGM is most prevalent in Saudi regions following [[Shafi'i]] school within the Sunni sect of Islam, such as [[Hejaz]], Tihamah and Asir.<ref>Berg, R. C., Denison, E., & Fretheim, A. (2010). Psychological, social and sexual consequences of female genital. Report from Kunnskapssenteret, (13), Norway</ref><ref>[http://2001-2009.state.gov/g/wi/rls/rep/9276.htm FGM Prevalence] US Department of State (2001)</ref><ref>Al-Sharabasi, Ahmad (1980), Yas'alunak fi al-din wal-hayat, 4th Edition, II, pp 31; also see I:253-255</ref> In a clinical study, Alsibiani and Rouzi provide evidence of the practice in Saudi Arabia.<ref>Alsibiani, S. A., & Rouzi, A. A. (2010). Sexual function in women with female genital mutilation. Fertility and sterility, 93(3), 722-724</ref> Another 2010 report claims post-FGM medical complications are an indicator of widespread prevalence of the practice in Saudi women.<ref>Rouzi, A. A. (2010). Epidermal clitoral inclusion cysts: not a rare complication of female genital mutilation. Human reproduction, 25(7), 1672-1674</ref> A 2012 study finds, that of the Saudi women who had FGM, Type III was more common than Type I or II.<ref>Berg, R. C., & Denison, E. (2012). Does female genital mutilation/cutting (FGM/C) affect women’s sexual functioning? A systematic review of the sexual consequences of FGM/C. Sexuality research and social policy, 9(1), 41-56</ref>
===Syria=== Circumstantial evidence suggests FGM exists in [[Syria]].<ref name=Birch/><ref name="fgmnetwork.org"/> A 2012 conference confirmed that FGM is observed in Syria.<ref name="gulfnews.com"/>
===Turkey=== Though there is little hard evidence of the practice of FGM in Turkey, circumstantial evidence suggests FGM exists in the southern Turkey where the majority of the population is Kurdish.<ref name=Birch/><ref>[http://www.khrp.org/khrp-news/human-rights-documents/briefing-papers/doc_download/218-the-practice-of-female-genital-mutilation-fgm-in-the-kurdish-regions.html The Practice of Female Genital Mutilation (FGM) in the Kurdish Regions] Acharya (2009), Kurdish Human Rights Project</ref>
===United Arab Emirates=== The WHO mentions a study that documents FGM in the [[United Arab Emirates]], but does not provide data.<ref name="irinnews.org"/><ref>[http://whqlibdoc.who.int/publications/2008/9789241596442_eng.pdf "Eliminating Female Genital Mutilation: An interagency statement"], World Health Organization, 2008, p. 30.</ref> The practice is reportedly prevalent in rural and urban UAE.<ref name="Kvello_2003">{{Cite conference |first = Ane |last = Kvello |author2=Sayed L |author3=Sundby J |title = Concerning female circumcision in the United Arab Emirates: Is clitoridectomy in a traditional context an assault against women? |booktitle = FOKO 2003 – ABSTRACTS |publisher = University of Oslo |date = 2003-09-06 |url = http://www.med.uio.no/iasam/inthel/foko/invitation.html}}</ref>) In a 2011 survey, 34% of Emirati female respondents said FGM had been performed on them, and explained the practice to customs and tradition.<ref name=tnuae11>[http://www.thenational.ae/lifestyle/fatal-traditions-female-circumcision-in-the-uae#full Fatal traditions: Female circumcision in the UAE] Wafa Al Marzouqi (Jul 23, 2011), The National, United Arab Emirates</ref> FGM is a controversial topic in UAE, and people argue about whether it is an Islamic requirement or a tribal tradition. A significant number of UAE nationals follow in the footsteps of their parents and grandparents without questioning the practice. A 2012 report published by UAE government scores UAE at 31% on prevalence of Female Genital Mutilation.<ref>[http://www.dwe.gov.ae/data2/Book_I.pdf UAE Women Index Report 2012] Shamsa Saleh, UAE (2012)</ref>
===Yemen=== According to a 2008 UNICEF report, 30% prevalence;<ref name="applications.emro.who.int"/> in addition to the adult prevalence, UNICEF reports that 20% of women aged 15–49 have a daughter who had the procedure in [[Yemen]].<ref name="fgmnetwork.org"/><ref name="irinnews.org"/><ref>[http://www2.unicef.org/infobycountry/yemen_statistics.html At a glance: Yemen – Statistics], UNICEF, accessed 5 February 2011.</ref> In 4 of Yemen's 21 governorates, according to a 2008 report, the FGM prevalence rates exceed 80%: [[Al Hudaydah Governorate|al-Hudaydah]] (97%), [[Hadhramaut Governorate|Hadhramaut]] (97%), [[Al Mahrah Governorate|al-Mahrah]] (97%) and [['Adan Governorate|Adan]] (82%); [[Sana'a Governorate]], which includes the capital of Yemen, has a prevalence rate of 46%.<ref name="YEMEN 2008">[http://www.irinnews.org/report/79025/yemen-government-body-moves-to-stem-female-genital-mutilation YEMEN: Government body moves to stem female genital mutilation] IRIN, A news service of the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (2008)</ref> Type II FGM was most common, accounting for 83% of all FGMs. Type I FGMs accounted for 13%.<ref name="YEMEN 2008"/>
Yemeni tradition is to carry out the FGM on a new born, with 97% of FGM being done within the first month of a baby girl. In 2001, Yemen banned FGM in all private and public medical facilities by a government decree, but not homes. The Yemeni government did not enforce this decree. In 2009, conservative Yemeni parliamentarians opposed the adoption of a nationwide criminal law against FGM.<ref>[http://www.giz.de/Themen/de/dokumente/giz-fgm-EN-jemen-2011.pdf Female Genital Mutilation in Yemen] Federal Ministry of Economic Cooperation and Development, Germany (September 2011)</ref> In 2010, the Ministry of Human Rights of Yemen launched a new study to ascertain over 4 years if FGM is being practiced in Yemen, then propose a new law against FGM.<ref>[http://www.irinnews.org/report/88058/yemen-new-fgm-c-law-possible-within-four-years-minister YEMEN: New FGM/C law possible "within four years" - minister] IRIN, A news service of the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (2010)</ref> A 2013 UNICEF report claims Yemen's FGM prevalence rate have not changed in last 30 years.<ref>[http://www.unicef.org/esaro/5440_13066.html Overwhelming opposition to female genital mutilation/cutting, yet millions of girls still at risk] UNICEF (July 2013)</ref>
==North America==
===Canada=== There is some evidence to indicate that FGM is practised in Ontario and across Canada among immigrant and refugee communities.<ref>{{cite web|title=FGM in Canada|url=http://www.ohrc.on.ca/en/policy-female-genital-mutilation-fgm/4-fgm-canada|website=Ontario Human Right Commission|publisher=Ontario Human Right Commission|accessdate=7 October 2014}}</ref> FGM is considered child assault and prohibited under sections 267 ([[assault causing bodily harm]]) or 268 ([[aggravated assault]], including wounding, maiming, disfiguring) of the [[Criminal Code (Canada)|Criminal Code]].<ref>{{citation|title=Female genital mutilation and health care – an exploration of the needs and roles of affected communities and health care providers in Canada|author=Federal Interdepartmental Working Group on Female Genital Mutilation|publisher=Health Canada|year=1999}} *[http://laws.justice.gc.ca/en/ShowDoc/cs/C-46/bo-ga:l_VIII Canada's Criminal Code ( R.S., 1985, c. C-46 )]</ref>
===United States=== {{main|Female genital mutilation in the United States}} The [[Centers for Disease Control]] estimated in 1997 that 168,000 girls living in the United States had undergone FGM or were at risk.<ref name=DuPont1998p85>Cullen-DuPont, Kathryn. "Female genital mutilation,"''Encyclopedia of Women's History in America''. Da Capo Press, 1998, [https://books.google.com/books?id=oIro7MtiFuYC&pg=PA85 p. 85].</ref> [[Khalid Adem]], a Muslim who had moved from Ethiopia to Atlanta, Georgia, became the first person to be convicted in the US in an FGM case; he was sentenced to ten years in 2006 for having severed his two-year-old daughter's clitoris with a pair of scissors.<ref>[http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/news/nation/2006-11-01-georgia_x.htm "Man gets 10-year sentence for circumcision of 2-year-old daughter"], Associated Press, 1 November 2006.</ref> Performing the procedure on anyone under the age of 18 became illegal in the U.S. in 1997 with the ''Federal Prohibition of Female Genital Mutilation Act''.<ref>Zabus 2004, p. 110.</ref>
As of 2018, 27 [[U.S. state]]s have specific laws against FGM.<ref>https://www.theahafoundation.org/female-genital-mutilation/</ref> States that do not have such laws may use other general statutes, such as assault, battery or [[child abuse]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://theahafoundation.org/wp/wp-content/uploads/2011/05/FGMLAWS_2013011.pdf |title=Female Genital Mutilation (FGM) Statutes in the United States & United Kingdom| accessdate=March 19, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130515174555/http://theahafoundation.org/wp/wp-content/uploads/2011/05/FGMLAWS_2013011.pdf |archivedate=May 15, 2013 }}</ref> The ''Transport for Female Genital Mutilation Act'' was passed in January 2013, and prohibits knowingly transporting a girl out of the U.S. for the purpose of undergoing FGM.<ref>Hassan, Yasmeen. [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/yasmeen-hassan/new-wins-speed-gains_b_2403941.html "As Global Consensus Accelerates, Obama Strengthens Federal Law Protecting Girls in the Fight Against Female Genital Mutilation"],''The Huffington Post'', 3 January 2013.</ref>
[[Matter of Kasinga|Fauziya Kasinga]], a 19-year-old member of the [[Tchamba]]-Kunsuntu tribe of Togo, was granted asylum in 1996 after leaving an [[arranged marriage]] to escape FGM; this set a precedent in US immigration law because it was the first time FGM was accepted as a form of persecution.<ref>Dugger, Celia W. [https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C05E1DB1439F935A25755C0A960958260 "June 9-15; Asylum From Mutilation"],''The New York Times'', 16 June 1996. *[http://www.justice.gov/eoir/efoia/kasinga7.pdf "In re Fauziya KASINGA, file A73 476 695], U.S. Department of Justice, Executive Office for Immigration Review, decided 13 June 1996. *Dugger, Celia W. [https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/15/nyregion/woman-s-plea-for-asylum-puts-tribal-ritual-on-trial.html "Woman's Plea for Asylum Puts Tribal Ritual on Trial"], ''The New York Times'', 15 April 1996.</ref>
In 2016, the [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)]] released a report compiled with data from 2010-2013. The 2013 study estimated 513,000 girls and women in the United States were either victims of FGM or at risk of FGM, with ⅓ under age 18.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://www.prb.org/Publications/Articles/2015/us-fgmc.aspx|title=Women and Girls at Risk of Female Genital Mutilation/Cutting in the United States|website=www.prb.org|access-date=2017-10-20}}</ref> The marked increase in the number of girls and women at risk of FGM in the United States was attributed to an increase in the total number of immigrants from countries where FGM is most common, not an increase in the frequency of the practice.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Goldberg|first=Howard|last2=Stupp|first2=Paul|last3=Okoroh|first3=Ekwutosi|last4=Besera|first4=Ghenet|last5=Goodman|first5=David|last6=Danel|first6=Isabella|date=2016|title=Female Genital Mutilation/Cutting in the United States: Updated Estimates of Women and Girls at Risk, 2012|journal=Public Health Reports|volume=131|issue=2|pages=340–347|doi=10.1177/003335491613100218|issn=0033-3549|pmc=4765983|pmid=26957669}}</ref>
==South America==
===Colombia=== The only indigenous tribe in Latin America known to practise FGM is Colombia's [[Emberá people]]. The tradition was extremely secretive and taboo until a 2007 incident, in which a girl died as a result of FGM. The incident caused much controversy, raised awareness and stimulated debate about ending the practice altogether. In 2015, it was reported that of the approximately 250,000 members of the tribe, 25,000 (10%) had decided to discontinue female genital mutilation, with a community leader saying they hoped to eradicate it by 2030.<ref name=Moloney>{{cite web|last1=Moloney|first1=Anastasia|title=Colombia's Embera tribe hopes to eradicate FGM by 2030|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/02/06/us-colombia-girls-fgm-idUSKBN0LA2FX20150206|website=Reuters|accessdate=6 August 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150714145347/https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/02/06/us-colombia-girls-fgm-idUSKBN0LA2FX20150206|archivedate=14 July 2015|date=6 February 2015}}</ref>
==Oceania==
===Australia===
In 1994 there were several anecdotal reports of FGM being practised amongst migrant communities in Australia.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.murdoch.edu.au/elaw/issues/v9n3/spencer93_text.html|title=The Criminalisation Of Female Genital Mutilation In Queensland|publisher=Murdoch University Electronic Journal of Law|date=September 2002}}</ref> By 1997, all Australian states and territories had made FGM a criminal offence. It is also a criminal offence to take, or propose to take, a child outside Australia to have a FGM procedure performed.<ref>{{citation|title=Female Genital Mutilation: Information for Australian Health Professionals|author=Royal Australian College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists|publisher=Royal Australian College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists|year=1997}}</ref> The [[Incidence (epidemiology)|incidence]] of FGM in Australia is unknown as it is often only uncovered when women and girls are taken to hospital due to complications with the procedure.<ref>[http://www.news.com.au/story/0,23599,20701170-2,00.html "Girls mutilated for 'tradition'"], ''The Sunday Telegraph'', 5 November 2006.</ref> In 2015 two unnamed women became the first people in Australia to be convicted of carrying out FGM; their case was also the first time such an offense had come to trial in Australia.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-australia-34795203 |title=Australia convicts two over female genital mutilation - BBC News |publisher=Bbc.com |date= |accessdate=2015-11-14}}</ref>
In 2017 the first national study by researches at the [[Westmead Children's Hospital]] in Sydney found 59 girls having attended medical staff since 2010, with many having had the most extreme form of the procedure done to them. A fifth of those had [[infibulation]], the removal of the clitoris and external genitalia with the opening sewed up. The number was deemed to strongly underestimate the true number of cases. Most of the procedures had been done overseas, but two children born in Australia had the procedure done in [[New South Wales]] and a third child born in Australia had been taken to Indonesia to have the procedure done. Of the 59 girls, only 13 had been in contact with child protection services.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.abc.net.au/news/2017-01-13/report-on-female-genital-mutilation-shows-hidden-prevalence/8180340|title=Months-old babies subjected to female genital mutilation, report finds|date=2017-01-13|work=ABC News|access-date=2018-11-09|language=en-AU}}</ref> Most (about 90%) were identified during refugee screening and had African origin.<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Zurynski|first=Yvonne|last2=Phu|first2=Amy|last3=Sureshkumar|first3=Premala|last4=Cherian|first4=Sarah|last5=Deverell|first5=Marie|last6=Elliott|first6=Elizabeth J.|date=2017-06-01|title=Female genital mutilation in children presenting to Australian paediatricians|url=https://adc.bmj.com/content/102/6/509|journal=Archives of Disease in Childhood|language=en|volume=102|issue=6|pages=509–515|doi=10.1136/archdischild-2016-311540|issn=0003-9888|pmid=28082321}}</ref>The report also stated that there was no FGM registry in Australia and even when detected is not routinely reported. The two most common countries of birth for the girls were Somalia (24) and Eritrea (12).<ref name=":3" />
===New Zealand=== Under a 1995 amendment to the Crimes Act, it is illegal to perform "any medical or surgical procedure or mutilation of the vagina or clitoris of any person" for reasons of "culture, religion, custom or practice". It is also illegal to send or make any arrangement for a child to be sent out of New Zealand for FGM to be performed, assist or encourage any person in New Zealand to perform FGM on a New Zealand citizen or resident outside New Zealand convince or encourage any other New Zealand citizen or resident to go outside New Zealand to have FGM performed.<ref>[http://www.fgm.co.nz/ "Female Genital Mutilation: Information for health and child protection professionals], New Zealand Ministry of Health, accessed 7 September 2011.</ref>
==South, Southeast and Central Asia== Anti-FGM organisations in Asia have complained that global attention on eradicating FGM goes almost entirely to Africa.<ref name="Batha">{{Cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-global-fgm-conference/in-parts-of-asia-and-middle-east-female-genital-mutilation-a-hidden-ritual-idUSKBN15E0KF |title=In parts of Asia and Middle East, female genital mutilation a hidden ritual |author=Emma Batha |work=Reuters |date=30 January 2017 |accessdate=4 August 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.stopfgmmideast.org/background/unicefs-limited-numbers-female-genital-mutilation-much-more-widespread/ |title=No “African problem” |author=Oliver M. Piecha |publisher=Stop FGM Middle East |date=1 December 2013 |accessdate=5 August 2018}}</ref> Consequently, few studies have been done into FGM in Asian countries, complicating anti-FGM campaigns due to a lack of data on the phenomenon. Indian activist Masooma Ranalvi, who underwent FGM as a 7-year-old, was quoted as saying: "[T]he entire discourse on FGM up to now has centred on Africa. Africa of course needs attention but maybe there are other places where the focus can be spread to."<ref name="Batha"/>
===Afghanistan=== {{Expand section|date=November 2014}} Female genital mutilation is present in [[Afghanistan]],<ref name="autogenerated588">{{Cite book| publisher = Brill Academic Publishers| title = Encyclopedia of Women & Islamic Cultures: Family, Body, Sexuality and Health, Volume 3 (Encyclopaedia of Women and Islamic Cultures)| page = 588| year = 2005}}</ref> mainly in south border connecting to Pakistan.
===Brunei=== {{Expand section|date=November 2014}} Female genital mutilation Type IV is present in Brunei.<ref>[http://www.bt.com.bn/news-national/2012/06/16/female-circumcision-cultural-practice "Female circumcision is cultural practice"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140520173717/http://www.bt.com.bn/news-national/2012/06/16/female-circumcision-cultural-practice# |date=2014-05-20 }}, The Brunei Times, 16 June 2012.</ref>
===India=== {{main|Female genital mutilation in India}} The practice of FGM constitutes a criminal offense under the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act, 2012; Indian Penal Code, 1860 and Criminal Procedure Code, 1973.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.india.com/news/agencies/ipc-pocso-enough-to-deal-with-female-genital-mutilation-govt-2379132/|title=IPC, POCSO enough to deal with female genital mutilation: Govt|first=PTI|last=Feeds|date=4 August 2017|publisher=}}</ref> Estimates suggest 90% of females in the Ismaili Shia Muslim [[Dawoodi Bohra|Bohra]] community in [[India]] undergo FGM.<ref name="hindustantimes.com"/><ref>[http://www.outlookindia.com/article.aspx?279088 The Yin, Wounded - A primitive rite for Bohra women sees its first murmurs of protest] DEBARSHI DASGUPTA, Outlook India (December 2011)</ref> There are about 2 million Bohras in India.In a survey, over 70% Bohra respondents said an untrained professional had performed the procedure on them. Female genital cutting is being practiced in Kerala was found on August 2017 by [[Sahiyo]] reporters. Apart from the mental trauma, the women also said it also led to physical complications.{{citation needed|date=August 2017}}
On May 9, 2017 the [[Supreme Court of India]] sought a response from the Centre and four states (Maharashtra, Delhi, Gujarat and Rajasthan) on the validity of Female Genital Mutilation (FGM) when Public Interest Litigation by some Bohra women to ban the practice.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/india-news/sc-seeks-govt-response-to-plea-seeking-ban-on-female-genital-mutilation/story-NpLEnSLmg7wcQHnsboUlQI.html|title=SC seeks govt response to plea seeking ban on female genital mutilation|date=8 May 2017|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.livelaw.in/sc-issues-notice-on-pil-seeking-complete-ban-on-female-genital-mutilation-read-petition/|title=SC Issues Notice On PIL Seeking Complete Ban On Female Genital Mutilation [Read Petition] - Live Law|date=8 May 2017|publisher=}}</ref> On July 9, 2018, [[Attorney General of India]] [[K. K. Venugopal]] reiterated the Indian government's position that FGM was a violation of a person's fundamental rights and that its practice resulted in serious health complications for the girl concerned.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://indianexpress.com/article/india/supreme-court-questions-practice-of-female-genital-mutilation-5252532/|title=SC questions practice of female genital mutilation, says it violates ‘integrity’ of a girl child|date=9 July 2018|publisher=Indian Express}}</ref>
===Indonesia=== Female genital mutilation Type I and IV is prevalent in [[Indonesia]];<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2008/01/20/magazine/20circumcision-t.html A Cutting Tradition] Sara Corbett, New York Times (January 20, 2008)</ref><ref name=ahin>[https://www.theguardian.com/society/2012/nov/18/female-genital-mutilation-circumcision-indonesia The day I saw 248 girls suffering genital mutilation] Abigail Haworth, The Guardian United Kingdom, (November 17, 2012)</ref><ref>[http://www.hawaii.edu/hivandaids/Male%20and%20Female%20Genital%20Cutting%20Among%20Yogyakartans%20and%20Madurans.pdf Male and Female Genital Cutting among Yagyakartans and Madurans] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140812063405/http://www.hawaii.edu/hivandaids/Male%20and%20Female%20Genital%20Cutting%20Among%20Yogyakartans%20and%20Madurans.pdf# |date=2014-08-12 }} Muhadjir Darwin et al. (2004), Gadjah Mada University, Indonesia</ref><ref name="Female Circumcision in Indonesia">{{cite web|title=Female Circumcision in Indonesia|url=http://pdf.usaid.gov/pdf_docs/PNACU138.pdf|website=usaid.gov|publisher=United States Agency for International Development|accessdate=26 April 2015}}</ref> 97.5%<ref name="Female Circumcision in Indonesia"/> of the surveyed females from Muslim families (Muslim females are at least 85%<ref name="sp2010">{{cite web |url=http://sp2010.bps.go.id/index.php/site/tabel?tid=321&wid=0 |title=Penduduk Menurut Wilayah dan Agama yang Dianut |date=15 May 2010 |work=Sensus Penduduk 2010 |publisher=Badan Pusat Statistik |location=Jakarta, Indonesia |trans-title=Population by Region and Religion |accessdate=26 April 2015 |quote=Religion can be divided into Muslim, Protestant, Catholic, Hindu, Buddhist, Hu Khong Chu, and Other Religion.}} Muslim 207176162 (87.18%), Christian 16528513 (6.96), Catholic 6907873 (2.91), Hindu 4012116 (1.69), Buddhist 1703254 (0.72), Khong Hu Chu 117091 (0.05), Other 299617 (0.13), Not Stated 139582 (0.06), Not Asked 757118 (0.32), Total 237641326</ref> of females in Indonesia) are mutilated by age 18 (55 million females as of 2018). In certain communities of Indonesia, mass female circumcision (''khitanan massal'') ceremony are organized by local Islamic foundations around Prophet Muhammad’s birthday. Some FGM are Type IV done with a pen knife, others are Type I done with scissors. Two Indonesian nationwide studies in 2003 and 2010 found over 80% of the cases sampled involved cutting, typically of newborns through the age of 9. The surveys demonstrated that circumcision among girls and boys is a universal practice in the study sites, in all of which Islam was the primary religion. Across the sites, among all the children aged 15–18, 86-100% of the girls were reported already circumcised. More than 90% of families visited in the studies claimed they wanted the practice to continue.<ref name=ahin/><ref>[http://pdf.usaid.gov/pdf_docs/PNACU138.pdf Female Circumcision in Indonesia] Population Council and USAID, September 2003; see pages 24-27 and full report</ref>
Historical records suggest female circumcision in Indonesia started and became prevalent with the arrival of Islam in the 13th century as part of its drive to convert people to Islam. In islands of Indonesia, where partial populations converted to Islam in the 17th century, FGM has been prevalent in Muslim females only.<ref>William Clarence-Smith, Self-determination and Women's Rights in Muslim Societies (edited by Raghavan and Levine); pp 127-134, Brandeis University Press (2012), {{ISBN|978-1-61168-280-9}}.</ref><ref>A. Feillard and L. Morcoes (1998), [http://www.persee.fr/web/revues/home/prescript/article/arch_0044-8613_1998_num_56_1_3495 Female Circumcision in Indonesia: To Islamize in Ceremony or Secrecy] Persee, Vol. 56, Issue 56, pages 337-367</ref> In 2006, FGM was banned by the government but FGM/C remained commonplace for women in Indonesia - the world’s largest Muslim nation.<ref>[http://www.irinnews.org/report.aspx?ReportId=90366 "INDONESIA: Female genital mutilation persists despite ban"], IRIN Global, 2 September 2010.</ref> In 2010, the Indonesian Health Ministry issued a decree outlining the proper procedure for FGM, which activists claim contradicted the 2006 ruling prohibiting clinics from performing any FGM.<ref>[ Female circumcision decree must be revoked: NGOs] Dessy Sagita, The Jakarta Globe (June 23, 2011)</ref>
In 2013, the [[Indonesian Ulema Council]] ruled that it favors FGM, stating that although it is not mandatory, it is still “morally recommended”.<ref>Mathias Hariyadi, [http://www.asianews.it/news-en/Indonesian-Ulema-in-favour-of-female-circumcision:-a-human-right-26948.html Indonesian Ulema in favour of female circumcision: a "human right"’, Asia News, Jakarta (24 Jan 2013)]</ref> The Ulema has been pushing Indonesian government to circumcise girls, claiming it is part of Islamic teachings.<ref>[http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2013/01/22/mui-pushes-govt-circumcise-girls.html MUI pushes government to circumcise girls] The Jakarta Post, Indonesia (January 22, 2013)</ref> Some Indonesian officials, in March 2013, claimed cutting and pricking type circumcision is not FGM.<ref>[http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2013/03/25/asia-pacific/female-circumcision-not-mutilation-jakarta/#.UksSxSi5N5g Female circumcision not mutilation: Jakarta] Agence France Presse, The Japan Times (March 25, 2013)</ref> In 2014 the government criminalized all forms of FGM after it repealed exceptions to the laws.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2016/09/26/indonesia-seeks-end-female-genital-mutilation|title=Indonesia Seeks End to Female Genital Mutilation|date=26 September 2016|publisher=}}</ref>
According to 2016 report by UNICEF, 49% of Indonesian girls of age below 14 had already undergone FGM/C by 2015.<ref>[http://data.unicef.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/FGMC-2016-brochure_250.pdf UNICEF Data on FGM/C] UNICEF, page 4</ref>
===Malaysia=== Female genital mutilation Type I is prevalent in [[Malaysia]], where 93%<ref>{{cite web|author=Gabrielle Paluch in Pattani province |url=https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2015/apr/01/thailand-muslim-south-authorities-blind-eye-fgm-who |title=In Thailand’s Muslim south, authorities turn a blind eye to FGM | Global development |publisher=The Guardian |date= |accessdate=2015-11-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/asia-pacific/2015/03/female-genital-cutting-thailand-south-150309083458995.html |title=Female genital cutting in Thailand's south |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=2015-04-02 |accessdate=2015-11-14}}</ref> of females from Muslim families (about 9 million females) in an unpublished study have been mutilated.<ref name=md2012>[https://web.archive.org/web/20131004225752/http://spm.um.edu.my/news/20120503-female-circumcision-My-USM/index.php The Practice of Female Circumcision in Malaysia] Maznah Dahlui, Faculty of Medicine, University of Malaya, Malaysia (May 10, 2012)</ref><ref>[http://epostersonline.s3.amazonaws.com/rcog2013/rcog2013.4df0243.NORMAL.pdf Knowledge and acceptance of Female Circumcision] Khalid et al., Universiti Sains Islam Malaysia (2013)</ref><ref>{{Cite journal| title = The practice of female circumcision among Muslims in Kelantan, Malaysia| publisher =|vauthors=Rahman Isa A, Shuib R, Shukri Othman M | date = May 1999| volume = 7| issue = 13| journal = Reproductive Health Matters| pages = 137–144| doi = 10.1016/S0968-8080(99)90125-8}}</ref> It is widely considered as a female sunnah tradition (''sunat perempuan''), typically in the old days done by midwife (''mak bidan'') and now by medical physician. It is either a minor prick or cutting off a small piece of the highest part of clitoral hood and foreskin (Type I).<ref name=timalay>[http://www.theislamicmonthly.com/a-tiny-cut-female-circumcision-in-south-east-asia/ "A Tiny Cut": Female Circumcision in South East Asia] The Islamic Monthly (March 12 20313)</ref> Malaysian women claim religious obligation (82%) as the primary reason for female circumcision, with hygiene (41%) and cultural practice (32%) as other major motivators for FGM prevalence.<ref name=md2012/><ref name=timalay/>
Malaysia is a multicultural society, FGM is prevalent in Muslim community, and not observed in its minority Buddhist and Hindu communities.<ref name=timalay/><ref>Dahlui, Wong and Choo (2012), Female circumcision (FC) in Malaysia: Medicalization of a religious practice. Int. J. Behav. Med., 19 (Suppl 1):S7</ref> Malaysia has no laws in reference to FGM.<ref>[http://www.ipu.org/wmn-e/fgm-prov-m.htm "Legislation and other national provisions"], Inter-Parliamentary Union, accessed 21 November 2010.</ref> The Malaysian government sponsored 86th conference of Malaysia’s Fatwa Committee National Council of Islamic Religious Affairs held in April 2009 decided that female circumcision is part of Islamic teachings and it should be observed by Muslims, with the majority of the jurists in the Committee concluding that female circumcision is obligatory (''wajib''). The ''fatwa'' noted harmful circumcision methods are to be avoided.<ref>[http://www.e-fatwa.gov.my/fatwa-kebangsaan/hukum-pemotongan-genitalia-wanita-female-genital-mutilation Hukum Pemotongan Genitalia Wanita (Female Genital Mutilation)] Jabatan Kemajuan Islam Malaysia, Rasmi Fatwa, Government of Malaysia (2009)</ref> In 2012, Malaysian government health ministry proposed guidelines to reclassify and allow female circumcision as a medical practice.<ref>[http://www.abc.net.au/news/2012-12-07/an-malaysia-debate-over-female-circumcision/4416298 Malaysia storm over female circumcision] ABC News Australia (December 7, 2012)</ref>
===Maldives=== Female genital mutilation is practiced in [[Maldives]].<ref name="smh.com.au"/><ref>[http://calhoun.nps.edu/public/bitstream/handle/10945/10724/11Dec_Amir.pdf?sequence=1 Islamism and radicalism in the Maldives] Hasan Amir, Calhoun (CA, United States); see page 59-62</ref> Maldives' Attorney General Husnu Suood claims FGM was eradicated from Maldives by the 1990s, but the practice of female circumcision in Maldives is reviving because of Islamic fatwas from religious scholars in Maldives who preach that it as compulsory.<ref>[http://www.haveeru.com.mv/news/28292 Attorney General: Practice of female circumcision gaining momentum in Addu] Haveeru, Maldives (December 12, 2009)</ref> Religious leaders have renewed their calls for FGM in 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://minivannews.com/politics/figh-academy-vp-endorses-female-genital-mutilation-77037 |title=Figh Academy VP endorses female genital mutilation | Minivan News – Archive |publisher=Minivannews.com |date=2014-02-06 |accessdate=2015-11-14}}</ref>
===Pakistan=== Female genital mutilation is practiced among some [[Pakistan]]i communities, according to sources dated to the 1990s and 2000s.<ref name="unfpa1">[http://www.unfpa.org/gender/practices2.htm Mutilation/Cutting: Promoting Gender Equality], UNFPA, accessed 5 February 2011.</ref> Gibeau reports, for example, FGM is widespread in Bohra Muslims of Pakistan.<ref name="Gibeau, A. M. 1998"/><ref>Magoha & Magoha (2000), Current global status of female genital mutilation: a review. East African medical journal, 77(5)</ref> The [[Siddi#Sheedis of Pakistan|Sheedi Muslim community of Pakistan]], considered to be of Arab-African origins, practice FGM.<ref>[http://www.irinnews.org/fr/report/94534/pakistan-low-awareness-of-hidden-fgm-c-practices PAKISTAN: Low awareness of hidden FGM/C practices] IRIN, Karachi, 2011</ref> The practice is also found in Muslim communities near Pakistan's Iran-Balochistan border.<ref>[http://blogs.tribune.com.pk/story/15979/female-genital-mutilation-many-pakistani-womens-painful-secret/ Female Genital Mutilation: Many Pakistani women’s painful secret] Farahnaz Zahidi, February 6, 2013</ref>
===Philippines=== Female genital mutilation is prevalent in parts of the [[Philippines]].<ref name=casalin>[https://web.archive.org/web/20141129023751/http://som.adzu.edu.ph/research/pdf/2008-06-25-135433casalin%2Cs..pdf Female Circumcision Among Yakan in Basilan, Philippines] Sittinurussamsi A. Calsalin, Ateneo de Zamboanga University (April 2008)</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Gilbert | first1 = D. | title = For the sake of purity (and control). Female genital mutilation | journal = Links | volume = 9 | issue = 5 | pages = 6–8, 30 | year = 1993 | pmid = 12159278}}</ref><ref>Maria Kontoyannis and Christos Katsetos, Female genital mutilation, Health Sciences Journal, Vol 4, Issue 1 (2010)</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Manalocon-Basher|first1=Salmah Lao|title=The Physical and Psychosocial Functionalities of Female Circumcision Practice among Meranaos, Mindanao, Philippines|journal=IAMURE: International Journal of Multidisciplinary Research|date=2014|volume=9|issue=1|url=http://ejournals.ph/article.php?id=2645|accessdate=19 May 2016|doi=10.7718/iamure.v9i1.840}}</ref> The communities that practice FGM call it ''Pag-Sunnat'', sometimes ''Pag-Islam'', and include Tausugs of [[Mindanao]], Yakan of [[Basilan]] and other Muslim communities of Philippines. FGM is typically performed on girls between a few days old and age 8. Type IV FGM with complications has been reported.<ref name=casalin/><ref>[http://ejournals.ph/article.php?id=6955 Muslim Women and Circumcision: "A Study of Intergenerational Practice and Its Continuity In Southern Philippines"] Olga Czarina Velayo Belisario, WMSU Research Journal, Vol 28, No 1 (2009)</ref>
===Singapore=== Female genital mutilation is practiced by the Malay Muslim community in [[Singapore]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Marranci|first1=Gabriele|title=Female circumcision in multicultural Singapore: The Hidden Cut|journal=The Australian Journal of Anthropology|date=February 2014|doi=10.1111/taja.12070|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/taja.12070/abstract|accessdate=19 April 2015|volume=26|issue=2|pages=276–292}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Taha|first1=Sya|title="A Tiny Cut": Female Circumcision in South East Asia|url=http://www.theislamicmonthly.com/a-tiny-cut-female-circumcision-in-south-east-asia/|website=The Islamic Monthly|accessdate=19 April 2015|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6XusYcv29?url=http://theislamicmonthly.com/a-tiny-cut-female-circumcision-in-south-east-asia/|archivedate=19 April 2015|date=12 March 2013}}</ref>
===Sri Lanka=== Female genital mutilation is practiced by the Muslim minority in Sri Lanka.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Senanayake|first1=Renuka|title=Sri Lanka - Culture: Mothers Watch as Daughters are Circumcised|url=http://www.ipsnews.net/1996/08/sri-lanka-culture-mothers-watch-as-daughters-are-circumcised/|website=Inter Press Service News Agency|publisher=IPS|accessdate=9 August 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150809043802/http://www.ipsnews.net/1996/08/sri-lanka-culture-mothers-watch-as-daughters-are-circumcised/|archivedate=9 August 2015|date=19 August 1996}}</ref>
===Thailand=== Female genital mutilation is practised by the Muslim population in the south of Thailand.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Paluch|first1=Gabrielle|title=Female genital cutting in Thailand's south|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/asia-pacific/2015/03/female-genital-cutting-thailand-south-150309083458995.html|website=Al Jazeera|publisher=Al Jazeera Media Network|accessdate=20 July 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150709150321/http://www.aljazeera.com/news/asia-pacific/2015/03/female-genital-cutting-thailand-south-150309083458995.html|archivedate=9 July 2015|date=2 April 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Merli|first1=Claudi|title=Sunat for girls in southern Thailand: its relation to traditional midwifery, male circumcision and other obstetrical practices.|journal=Finnish Journal of Ethnicity and Migration|date=2008|volume=3|issue=2|pages=32–41|url=http://dro.dur.ac.uk/5302/1/5302.pdf|accessdate=11 August 2015}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Asuda]] *[[Female genital mutilation]] *[[Prevalence of circumcision]] *[[Religious views on female genital mutilation]]
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==Further reading== * Ross, Susan Deller ''Women's Human Rights: The international and Comparative Law Casebook'', Vantage Press, 2008. For the legal situation in the US as of 2008.
==External links== * [http://www.africanchildforum.org/clr/Harmonisation%20of%20Laws%20in%20Africa/other-documents-harmonisation_11_en.pdf Laws on FGM in Africa] (according to a 2013 document compiled by the ''African Child Policy Forum (ACPF)'' - an independent, non-profit, pan-African organization focusing on African children) * [https://clarionproject.org/michigan-doctor-accused-of-performing-fgm-to-claim-freedom-of-religion-defense/ Michigan Doctor Accused of Performing FGM to Claim Freedom of Religion Defense]

revision.comment: Removing link(s): [[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/International Agency for the Prevention of Blindness]] closed as delete ([[WP:XFDC|XFDcloser]])
revision.text:
{{Infobox organization | name =Prevention of Blindness Trust | former name = | image = POB Trust Logo.png | image_border = | size = | alt = POB Trust logo | caption = | map = | msize = | malt = | mcaption = | map2 = | abbreviation = POB Trust, POB | motto = Prevention of avoidable blindness | predecessor = | successor = | formation = 2007 | extinction = | type = Free Eye Care [[Registered Trust]] | status = Registered Trust under Trust act of Pakistan. Tax Exempted. | purpose = Vision 2020 of WHO(World Health Organization) | headquarters = [[Lahore]] | location = [[Pakistan]] | coords = | region_served = Pakistan and Worldwide 20 Countries | membership = PIMA, FIMA, | language = | leader_title = Chairman | leader_name = [[Dr. Intzar Hussain Butt]] | general = Dr. Mohammad Zahid Latif | leader_title2 = [[Dr. Misbah Ul Aziz]] | leader_name2 = | leader_title3 = | leader_name3 = | leader_title4 = | leader_name4 = | key_people = | main_organ = | parent_organization = [[Pakistan Islamic Medical Association]] | affiliations = ECOSOC, WHO,http://www.emro.who.int/control-and-preventions-of-blindness-and-deafness/useful-links/useful-links.html FIMA, FIMA Save Vision, PIMA – See http://pima.org.pk/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=134:prevention-of-blindness&catid=25:pima-prevention-of-blindness&Itemid=58 | budget = | num_staff = | num_volunteers = | website = {{URL|http://www.pobtrust.org}} }} '''Prevention of Blindness Trust''', also known as the ''POB Trust'' and ''POB'', is a project of [[Pakistan Islamic Medical Association]].{{cite web |url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/400800/seminar-on-blindness-pima-to-build-hospital-for-free-eye-treatment/ |title=Seminar on blindness: PIMA to build hospital for free eye treatment |date=June 29, 2012 |work=The Express Tribune |accessdate=4 July 2012}}{{cite news |url=http://www.thenews.com.pk/Todays-News-4-117327-Doctors-to-conduct-eye-surgeries-in-Africa |title=Doctors to conduct eye surgeries in Africa |date=June 29, 2012 |work=The News |accessdate=4 July 2012 |location=Pakistan}} '''POB Trust''' was established and registered by Trust Act in July, 2007 as a leading volunteer eye care organization with the sole mission of preventing blindness and preserving sight. POB Trust was declared exempted from tax in 2012 by [[Federal Board of Revenue (Pakistan)]]http://pobtrust.org/pobdownloads/category/11-tax-exemption POB Trust endeavors to develop strategies for prevention and control of blindness and visual impairment. The prime objective of POB Trust is to promote and sustain a global campaign against all forms of avoidable blindness with emphasis on deprived communities. This initiative brings with it a great challenge and an exciting hope for all who work towards this goal. It is also a member of the International Agency for the Prevention of Blindness for the VISION 2020: The Right to Sight.http://pobtrust.org/about-pobtrust/core-values-and-strategy ==Activities== The POB Trust was registered in 2007, but the organization had been working in the field from 2005. Until May 2015, approximately US$56 million had been spent on its projects of free eye care services involving 115,194 Cataract Surgerieshttp://www.thefinancialdaily.com/epaper/Images/7-9-2013/2/2.jpg{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} of patients in 20 countries. POB Trust have been working in many areas: :* Free Eye Camps [[Pakistan]] :* Free Eye Camps in poor countries. :* Higher Surgical Training http://www.express.com.pk/epaper/PoPupwindow.aspx?newsID=1101754215&Issue=NP_ISB&Date=20130213 :* School Eye Care Services. :* Emergency Relief: Earth Quak, Floods, IDP's. :* Prison Eye Care. :* Social Activities. :* Blind Rehabilitation Program. :* Community Centers: Jarranwala District Faisalabad, Channan Kharian District Gujrat. :* POB Eye Hospitals : Lahore and Karachi :* Public Awareness Campaigns POB Trust organizes free eye camps in remote areas of the country. Every camp lasts for 2 to 4 days according to the location. During each free eye camp 1000-3000 patients are screened for cataracts and if diagnosed, they are referred for diagnostic tests including Hepatitis B,C Screening. Tests are performed free of cost in the camp. After passing these test patient goes towards surgery, and about 100-300 patients undergo the surgery in three days. Cataract-surgeries are done with Intra-ocular Lens implantation with small incision & Phaco-emulsification. In the out-patients reading glasses and eye drops are also distributed. [[File:Jaranwala-POB-HHRD-FreeEyeCamp-Sep2015 135.JPG|thumb|Free eye camp in Faisalabad district of Punjab Pakistan]] From 2005 to September 2016, the trust has achieved the following milestones: 22 countries in Asia and Africa 659 free eye camps Over one million, one hundred and fifty-seven thousand, nine hundred and thirty-six patients examined & treated. Over 124,526 operations with free lens implantation. (Mostly Cataract surgeries) Over 1 millions pairs of reading-glasses distributed. ==Partners== POB Trust worked in shared projects with many other organizations like [[International Islamic Relief Organization]] (IIRO), Akhwat, [[UK Islamic Mission]], [[Al Khidmat Foundation]], [[Federation of Islamic Medical Associations|FIMA]] Save Vision, Pak Trust UK, Helping Hand for Relief & Development, and with Ministry of Health Pakistan. ==POB Eye Hospitals== ===Lahore=== 7 kilometers Main Raiwind Road, Lahore ===Karachi=== Gulistan e Johar, Karachi [[File:Front of POB Trust Eye hospital Karachi Pakistan.jpg|thumb|Front view of POB Trust Eye hospital Karachi Pakistan (now working in rental building)]] POB Trust activities during this period were based in 20 countries, as follows: ==Countries of activities== Sudan, Chad, Somalia, Somali land, Nigeria,http://epaper.brecorder.com/2010/07/08/18-page/191321-news.htmlhttp://www.express.com.pk/epaper/PoPupwindow.aspx?newsID=1100991735&Issue=NP_LHE&Date=20100708 Mali, Senegal, Sri Lanka, Burkina Faso, Niger, Indonesia, Cameroon, Morocco, Zimbabwe, Gambia, Gaza Palestine, Bangladesh, South Africa, Maldives and Pakistan ==International Recognition== 1. Richard and Hinda Rosenthal award from The Rosenthal Family Foundation is given to Dr. Pervaiz Malik on Prevention of Blindness Services recognition. Date is 24 April 2009.http://fimaweb.net/cms/index.php/joomla-pages-iii/categories-list/71-projects/pob-trust/150-the-rosenthal-family-foundation{{cite web |url=http://www.acponline.org/about_acp/international/newsletter/july09/im09.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-06-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131003041344/http://www.acponline.org/about_acp/international/newsletter/july09/im09.htm |archivedate=2013-10-03 |df= }} 2. Pakistan Society of Ophthalmology award in 2011 http://www.osplhr.org/OSPWebpages/Archives/GoldMedalRecepients.pdf (see category 'OSP PICO Gold Medal on page 3) 3. Asia Pacific Academy of Ophthalmology Outstanding service in prevention of blindness Award http://www.apaophth.org/award_past.php#10 {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110904044837/http://www.apaophth.org/award_past.php |date=2011-09-04 }} ==Research Published== 1. Prevalence of Refractive Errors in a public school children of Lahore {{cite web |url=http://pjmhsonline.com/OctDec2014/prevalence_of_refractive_errors.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-06-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305191819/http://pjmhsonline.com/OctDec2014/prevalence_of_refractive_errors.htm |archivedate=2016-03-05 |df= }}
2. Private Public Mix Working Model of a Teaching Hospital, Benefits for the Organizations and End users{{cite web |url=http://pjmhsonline.com/octdec2013/private_public_mix_working_model.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-06-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305150210/http://pjmhsonline.com/octdec2013/private_public_mix_working_model.htm |archivedate=2016-03-05 |df= }} ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Blindness organizations]] [[Category:Medical and health organisations based in Pakistan]]

[[File:Skeleton Logo.png|thumb|423x423px]] '''Remote Area Medical Volunteer Corps''' (RAM) is a non-profit provider of mobile medical clinics delivering free dental, vision, and medical care (as well as veterinary services when available) to under-served and uninsured individuals.
== History == RAM was founded in 1985 by Englishman [[Stan Brock (philanthropist)|Stan Brock]], who worked as an assistant to [[Marlin Perkins]] on ''[[Mutual of Omaha's Wild Kingdom]]''.<ref>[https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0110633/ IMDB entry for Stan Brock]</ref> RAM's work was originally confined to Third World countries, but it later shifted towards the US.<ref>{{cite journal|last= Pelley |first= Scott |authorlink= Scott Pelley |date= February 28, 2008 |title= US Health Care gets boost from charity |journal= [[60 Minutes]] |volume= |series= |issue= |page= 4 |publisher= [[CBS News]] |id= |url= http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2008/02/28/60minutes/main3889496.shtml |accessdate= 2009-08-22 |quote= }}</ref> Today RAM works domestic operations around the United States and internationally when need arises.
The clinic in [[Wise, Virginia]] was recently recognized as the nation's largest pop-up free clinic.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/23/us/healthcare-uninsured-rural-poor-affordable-care-act-republicans.html|title=When Health Law Isn’t Enough, the Desperate Line Up at Tents|last=Gabriel|first=Trip|date=2017-07-23|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-08-28|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> The 2017 clinic in Wise hosted over 1,000 volunteers and served 2,300 men and women.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/27/opinion/remote-area-medical-health-care-republican.html|title=No Insurance, but for 3 Days, Health Care Is Within Reach|last=Kristof|first=Nicholas|date=2017-07-27|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-08-30|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>
RAM completed its 900th clinic in Knoxville Tennessee in 2018.
RAM were featured on an episode of ''[[60 Minutes]]'' on CBS.{{cn|date=August 2018}}
== Headquarters == On March 31, 2014, Remote Area Medical's headquarters moved from an old school building in Knox County to the previous [[Henniges Automotive]] facility in Blount County. The previous school building was utilized by RAM for 19 years and was rented by the organization for $1 a year from Knox County.
== Funding == RAM is funded through donations and relies on volunteers from the community, as well as professionals including physicians, dentists, optometrists, nurses, pilots and veterinarians to provide care in poorer communities.<ref>[http://timesfreepress.com/news/2008/apr/04/remote-area-medical-can-be-lifeline/?local Remote Area Medical can be a lifeline], Chattanooga Times Free Press</ref><ref>Mobile medical unit aids uninsured, [[The Washington Times]], July 21, 2008.</ref>
== Animal services == Remote Area Medical's Veterinary Program provides animal health services to those who live in underserved, impoverished, and isolated communities.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://ramusa.org/about/ "What We Do" Veterinary|title=About Us|last=|first=|date=2015-02-17|work=Remote Area Medical|access-date=2017-08-28|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US}}</ref>
== Disaster relief == Remote Area Medical's Disaster Relief arm responds to disasters by land, sea, and air, delivering medical relief and other humanitarian aid when needed.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://ramusa.org/disaster-relief/|title=Disaster Relief|date=2015-04-28|work=Remote Area Medical|access-date=2017-08-30|language=en-US}}</ref>
== Legislation == In 2017 Rep. John J. Duncan Jr., R-Knoxville, filed a bill that would provide $1 million to any state that allows licensed medical professionals to travel from other states and offer their services to those in need. The money would be a one-time allocation with the intent to help states pay any costs associated with allowing outside doctors to volunteer within their borders. The legislation, called the Healthier Act, specifies that out-of-state medical personnel could work only at weekend clinics. That would prevent them from moving into a state and setting up a permanent or semi-permanent practice.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.tennessean.com/story/news/2017/06/23/jimmy-duncan-charities-bill/423253001/|title=Knoxville group spawns push in Congress to ease rules on charitable health care providers|work=The Tennessean|access-date=2017-08-30|language=en}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.ramusa.org/ Official website] *{{cite news|first= Ariel |last= Leve |authorlink= Ariel S. Leve |title= Saint Stan Brock: who are you? |url= http://women.timesonline.co.uk/tol/life_and_style/women/ariel_leve/article6015125.ece |work= [[The Times]] |publisher= [[News International|Times Newspapers Limited]] |location= [[Wapping|Wapping, England]] |id= |page= |date= 2009-04-05 |accessdate= 2009-08-22 |archiveurl= |archivedate= }} *{{cite news|first= Guy |last= Adams |title= The brutal truth about America’s healthcare |url= https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/the-brutal-truth-about-americarsquos-healthcare-1772580.html |work= [[The Independent]] |publisher= [[Independent News & Media]] |location= London, England |id= |page= |date= 2009-08-15 |accessdate= 2009-08-22 |archiveurl= |archivedate= }} *{{cite news|first= Alice |last= Maggin |author2=Sadie Bass |title= Free Health Care for Those Who Need It Most |url= http://abcnews.go.com/WN/PersonOfWeek/story?id=8330961&page=1 |work= [[ABC News]] |publisher= [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] |location= [[Burbank, California]] |id= |page= |date= 2009-08-14 |accessdate= 2009-08-22 |archiveurl= |archivedate= }}

{{Infobox company | name = RxList| foundation = 1995| type = Health Information| homepage = [http://www.rxlist.com/ RxList.com]| owner = [[WebMD]] Since 2004| }}
'''RxList''', founded in 1995 by a pharmacist,<ref>{{cite web|title=The Human Side of Twitter About the Author|url=https://www.amazon.com/Human-Side-Twitter-Sandow-PharmD/dp/1448659833|publisher=Amazon.com|accessdate=31 January 2014}}</ref> is an online medical resource of US prescription medications providing full prescribing information and patient education. <ref>{{cite web|title=Site Info rxlist.com|url=http://cqcounter.com/site/rxlist.com.html|publisher=CQ Counter|accessdate=31 January 2014}}</ref>
RxList is an owned and operated site in the WebMD Consumer Network <ref>{{cite web|title=WebMD Corporate Site Consumer Network|url=http://www.wbmd.com/servicesconsumer.shtml|publisher=WebMD|accessdate=23 January 2014}}</ref> and was acquired by WebMD in December 2004.<ref>{{cite web|title=E-Health Market Overview and Internet Health Acquisitions|url=http://www.rightdiagnosis.com/ehealth/e-health-market.htm|publisher=Right Diagnosis|accessdate=24 January 2014}}</ref>
RxList provides content written by pharmacists and physicians and data provided by credible sources like the FDA, Cerner Multum, and First Data Bank, Inc..<ref>{{cite web|title=RxList About Us|url=http://www.rxlist.com/script/main/art.asp?articlekey=64467|publisher=RxList|accessdate=23 January 2014}}</ref>
RxList, as part of the WebMD Consumer Network, adheres to the same privacy policy as WebMD.com and is certified by the TRUSTe online privacy certification program. <ref>{{cite web|title=TRUSTe WebMD, LLC|url=http://privacy.truste.com/privacy-seal/WebMD,-LLC/validation?rid=7b3bf16d-37b4-42e0-aec7-836ef1d3680d|publisher=TRUSTe|accessdate=31 January 2014}}</ref>
RxList is ranked #14 in the January 2014 eBizMBA Top 15 Most Popular Health Websites. <ref>{{cite web|title=Top 15 Most Popular Health Websites January 2014|url=http://www.ebizmba.com/articles/health-websites|publisher=eBiz MBA|accessdate=27 January 2014}}</ref>
