revision.text:
{{Infobox Organization |name = Sisters of Charity of Saint Vincent de Paul |image = |image_border = |size = |caption = |map = |msize = |mcaption = |abbreviation = |motto = |formation = May 11, 1849 |extinction = |type = Religious organization |status = active |purpose = advocate and public voice, educator and network |headquarters = [[Halifax Regional Municipality]], [[Nova Scotia]] |location = |region_served = [[Canada]], eastern [[United States]], in [[Bermuda]], [[Peru]] and the [[Dominican Republic]]. |membership = |language = [[English Language|English]]
[[French language|French]] |leader_title = |leader_name = |main_organ = |parent_organization = [[Sisters of Charity Federation]]. |affiliations = [[Mount Saint Vincent University]] |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = [http://www.schalifax.ca/ Sisters of Charity of Saint Vincent de Paul] |remarks = }} The '''Sisters of Charity of Saint Vincent de Paul''' were founded on May 11, 1849, when the four founding Sisters of Charity arrived in [[City of Halifax|Halifax, Nova Scotia]], from [[New York City]]; this has been designated a [[Events of National Historic Significance (Canada)|National Historic Event]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.pc.gc.ca/apps/dfhd/page_nhs_eng.aspx?id=12033|title=Sisters of Charity of Saint Vincent de Paul, Halifax National Historic Event|access-date=2017-05-26}} ==History== The story of the Canadian foundation begins when four American ladies, black-robed, black-capped, landed in Halifax from the Cunard liner "Cambria" on May 11, 1849. They came from New York City, these first Sisters of Charity, in response to a standing request by Bishop [[William Walsh (archbishop)|William Walsh]] of Halifax to his friend Archbishop [[John Hughes (archbishop of New York)|John Hughes]] of New York for Sisters to work in his diocese in the care of orphans and in education. Halifax had a population of 20,000 when the four "American ladies" arrived. The Bishop gave them a house on [[Barrington Street]], near the cathedral, where they took in a little orphan girl on the very first day. They immediately opened a school to teach Catholic children, many of them Irish immigrants, victims of the potato famine. By the end of the school year (July) their classes held 400 children. By that time the Sisters were also caring for twenty little girls in their own house.{{Cite web|url=http://www.umanitoba.ca/colleges/st_pauls/ccha/Back%20Issues/CCHA1980/O'Gallagher.html|title=Marianna O'Gallagher, "The Sisters of Charity of Halifax - The Early and Middle Years"|last=|first=|date=|website=www.umanitoba.ca|access-date=2017-05-26}} They would be the first religious community in this maritime city. Mother Basilia McCann, leader of the original four Sisters who arrived here in 1849, became the first Superior of the Halifax Congregation. Mother Basilia was a pupil of [[Elizabeth Ann Seton|Elizabeth Seton]], founder of the first Sisters of Charity in 1809. She served as Superior for three years, then returned to the New York community. The second Superior to serve in Halifax was Sister Mary Rose McAleer, also one of the original group to come to Halifax in 1849. Shortly after their arrival the Sisters opened their first school, housed at St. Mary's Convent in the heart of the city. Halifax was still a growing city, and with no hospital yet established, the need for assistance spanned beyond education. The Sisters responded to this need. Within a short time they were also caring for the sick.[http://www.antigonishdiocese.com/charities.html "Sisters of Charity - Halifax", Archdiocese of Antigonish] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130330011223/http://www.antigonishdiocese.com/charities.html |date=2013-03-30 }} By 1856, the order in Halifax was accepted as a separate congregation by [[Pope Pius IX]] and took on their new official name, the "Sisters of Charity of St. Vincent de Paul, Halifax." Sister Mary Rose McAleer and two novices began teaching girls in St. Patrick's Parish in the North end of the city. At first they travelled daily to teach in the church basement. A house was soon rented for them, and thus began St. Patrick's Convent – and High School and Elementary School. St. Patrick's was the first of more than a hundred missions that would eventually be opened by the Sisters of Charity. When St Patrick’s moved to larger quarters in 1888, the former convent was converted into a refuge for unmarried mothers and their babies, named the Home of the Guardian Angel.{{Cite news|url=http://www.biographi.ca/en/bio.php?id_nbr=6146|title=Biography – HARRINGTON, JOANNA, Sister Mary Benedicta – Volume XII (1891-1900) – Dictionary of Canadian Biography|access-date=2017-05-26}} In 1866 victims of cholera were landed from an immigrant ship on McNab's Island in the harbour and when the Archbishop asked for helpers, all the Sisters volunteered. He chose three. That summer the increase in the number of orphans led to expansion of facilities. By September 1873, the Sisters moved into the newly built Motherhouse named Mount Saint Vincent.just outside Halifax. Sisters from the order first came to Boston, Massachusetts, in August 1887, called to staff a new school for girls at St. Patrick’s Parish in Roxbury.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/metro/2012/11/19/sisters-charity-celebrate-years-archdiocese-boston/UmczR2JC6MlD7VjluaRA2N/story.html|title=Sisters of Charity celebrate 125 years in Archdiocese of Boston - The Boston Globe|work=BostonGlobe.com|access-date=2017-05-26}} On April 30, 1880, Leo XIII issued a document removing from the Archbishop of Halifax "any jurisdiction" he had held over the Sisters of Charity, and placing the Congregation under the Pope's immediate control. The order founded Canada's best known women's university, now co-educational, [[Mount Saint Vincent University]] in Halifax, Nova Scotia. Mount Saint Vincent received its own college charter in 1925. A long tradition ended in 2006 when Sister Sheilagh Martin, a chemistry professor, retired as the last member of the congregation to teach there. They came to British Columbia in the 1920s, founding Seton Academy, Vancouver (1923). ==Charism== The charism of the Sisters of Charity of Halifax is rooted in the tradition of Saints [[Elizabeth Ann Seton]], [[Vincent de Paul]], and Louise de Marillac.{{Cite web |url=http://www.schalifax.ca/our-mission-2/# |title="Our Mission", Sisters of Charity - Halifax |access-date=2013-07-07 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150213004533/http://www.schalifax.ca/our-mission-2/# |archive-date=2015-02-13 |dead-url=yes |df= }} ==Ministry== The areas of education, health care, pastoral ministry, and social services are still paramount, though the ways in which the sisters work within a given field has changed. While the congregation once operated hospitals, schools, senior citizen homes, and the only women's university in Canada, sisters now serve in a variety of areas in Canada and throughout the eastern [[United States]], in [[Bermuda]], [[Peru]], and the [[Dominican Republic]].{{Cite web|url=http://rcav.org/srs-of-charity-of-st-vincent-de-paul-halifax-sch/|title=Sisters of Charity of St Vincent De Paul-Halifax (S.C.H.) - Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Vancouver|website=rcav.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-05-26}} In 1975, at the beatification of [[Saint Elizabeth Ann Seton]], there were approximately 1700 sisters in the organization and 97 missions.{{Cite web|url=http://www.emmitsburg.net/archive_list/articles/history/stories/sisters_of_charity.htm|title=A Short History of the Sisters of Charity|website=www.emmitsburg.net|access-date=2017-05-26}} Today, there are approximately 500 sisters[http://www.schalifax.ca/sub/01about/01who.html About the Sisters of Charity] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100315053708/http://www.schalifax.ca/sub/01about/01who.html |date=March 15, 2010 }} The headquarters of the [[religious institute]] is located in Halifax's [[Rockingham, Nova Scotia|Rockingham]] neighbourhood at the Sisters of Charity Centre. The original Motherhouse building, which also incorporated Mount Saint Vincent Academy and College (the precursors to the current University) was built around the time of the Academy's founding in 1873 and destroyed by fire in 1951. Rebuilt separately in the early 1950s, it housed retired sisters of the order as well as visiting religious and laypeople. It also housed for Mount Saint Vincent University a student residence called Vincent Hall until the residence was closed by the University in 1992. The building, once the largest in all of Atlantic Canada, was demolished in 2008. In 2011 the property was sold to developer Southwest Propoerties, Ltd. The first phase of the development includes residential and retail components. The development is to be known as Seton Ridge.{{Cite news|url=http://thechronicleherald.ca/business/1228693-pete-s-to-anchor-rockingham-development-on-former-motherhouse-site|title=Pete’s to anchor Rockingham development on former Motherhouse site|date=2014-08-11|work=The Chronicle Herald|access-date=2017-05-26|language=en}} The order is part of the [[Sisters of Charity Federation]]. Two growing interests for the order are ecological projects and helping victims of human trafficking, issues they are working on with the Leadership Conference of Women Religious. ==See also== *[[Catholic sisters and nuns in Canada]] *[[Sisters of Charity]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.schalifax.ca/ Sisters of Charity of Saint Vincent de Paul] [[Category:Catholic female orders and societies]] [[Category:Sisters of Charity Federation in the Vincentian-Setonian Tradition]] [[Category:Roman Catholic Ecclesiastical Province of Halifax]] [[Category:Religious organizations established in 1849]] [[Category:Catholic religious institutes established in the 19th century]] [[Category:Christian organizations based in Canada]] [[Category:1849 establishments in Nova Scotia]] [[Category:Non-profit organizations based in Nova Scotia]] [[Category:History of Halifax, Nova Scotia]] [[Category:Catholic Church in Canada]] [[Category:Catholic nursing orders]]

{{Infobox medical condition (new) | name = Subacromial bursitis | synonyms = | image = Joint.svg | caption = Typical joint | pronounce = | field = | symptoms = | complications = | onset = | duration = | types = | causes = | risks = | diagnosis = | differential = | prevention = | treatment = | medication = | prognosis = | frequency = | deaths = }} '''Subacromial bursitis''' is a condition caused by [[inflammation]] of the [[Synovial bursa|bursa]] that separates the superior surface of the [[supraspinatus muscle|supraspinatus]] tendon (one of the four tendons of the [[rotator cuff]]) from the overlying [[coraco-acromial ligament]], acromion, and coracoid (the acromial arch) and from the deep surface of the [[deltoid muscle]].<ref name=Salzman97/> The [[subacromial bursa]] helps the motion of the supraspinatus tendon of the rotator cuff in activities such as overhead work.
Musculoskeletal complaints are one of the most common reasons for primary care office visits, and rotator cuff disorders are the most common source of shoulder pain.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Arcuni SE |title=Rotator cuff pathology and subacromial impingement |journal=Nurse Pract |volume=25 |issue=5 |pages=58, 61, 65–6 passim |year=2000 |pmid=10826138 |doi= 10.1097/00006205-200025050-00005|url=}}</ref>
Primary inflammation of the subacromial bursa is relatively rare and may arise from autoimmune inflammatory conditions such as [[rheumatoid arthritis]]; crystal deposition disorders such as [[gout]] or [[pseudogout]]; calcific loose bodies, and infection.<ref name=Salzman97>{{cite journal |vauthors=Salzman KL, Lillegard WA, Butcher JD |title=Upper extremity bursitis |journal=Am Fam Physician |volume=56 |issue=7 |pages=1797–806, 1811–2 |year=1997 |pmid=9371010 |doi= |url=}}</ref> More commonly, subacromial [[bursitis]] arises as a result of complex factors, thought to cause shoulder [[Impingement syndrome|impingement]] symptoms. These factors are broadly classified as intrinsic (intratendinous) or extrinsic (extratendinous). They are further divided into primary or secondary causes of impingement. Secondary causes are thought to be part of another process such as shoulder instability or nerve injury.<ref name=Bigliani97>{{cite journal |vauthors=Bigliani LU, Levine WN |title=Subacromial impingement syndrome |journal=J Bone Joint Surg Am |volume=79 |issue=12 |pages=1854–68 |year=1997 |pmid=9409800 |doi= |url=http://www.ejbjs.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=9409800}}</ref>
In 1983 Neer described three stages of impingement syndrome.<ref name=Neer1983>{{cite journal |author=Neer CS |title=Impingement lesions |journal=Clin. Orthop. Relat. Res. |volume= |issue=173 |pages=70–7 |year=1983 |pmid=6825348 |doi= |url=http://meta.wkhealth.com/pt/pt-core/template-journal/lwwgateway/media/landingpage.htm?issn=0009-921X&volume=173&spage=70}}</ref> He noted that "the symptoms and physical signs in all three stages of impingement are almost identical, including the 'impingement sign'..., arc of pain, crepitus, and varying weakness". The Neer classification did not distinguish between partial-thickness and full-thickness rotator cuff tears in stage III.<ref name=Neer1983/> This has led to some controversy about the ability of physical examination tests to accurately diagnose between bursitis, impingement, impingement with or without rotator cuff tear and impingement with partial versus complete tears.
In 2005, Park et al. published their findings which concluded that a combination of clinical tests were more useful than a single physical examination test. For the diagnosis of impingement disease, the best combination of tests were "any degree (of) a positive [[Hawkins–Kennedy test]], a positive painful arc sign, and weakness in external rotation with the arm at the side", to diagnose a full thickness [[rotator cuff tear]], the best combination of tests, when all three are positive, were the painful arc, the drop-arm sign, and weakness in external rotation.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Park HB, Yokota A, Gill HS, El Rassi G, McFarland EG |title=Diagnostic accuracy of clinical tests for the different degrees of subacromial impingement syndrome |journal=J Bone Joint Surg Am |volume=87 |issue=7 |pages=1446–55 |year=2005 |pmid=15995110 |doi=10.2106/JBJS.D.02335 |url=http://www.ejbjs.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=15995110}}</ref>
==Signs and symptoms == Subacromial bursitis often presents with a constellation of symptoms called [[impingement syndrome]]. Pain along the front and side of the shoulder is the most common symptom and may cause weakness and stiffness.<ref name=Bigliani97/> If the pain resolves and weakness persists other causes should be evaluated such as a tear of the rotator cuff or a neurological problem arising from the neck or entrapment of the suprascapular nerve. The onset of pain may be sudden or gradual and may or may not be related to trauma. Night time pain, especially sleeping on the affected shoulder, is often reported. Localized redness or swelling are less common and suggest an infected subacromial bursa. Individuals affected by subacromial bursitis commonly present with concomitant shoulder problems such as [[arthritis]], rotator cuff [[tendinitis]], [[rotator cuff tear]]s, and [[cervical radiculopathy]] (pinched nerve in neck).
Impingement may be brought on by sports activities, such as overhead throwing sports and swimming, or overhead work such as painting, carpentry, or plumbing. Activities that involve repetitive overhead activity, or directly in front, may cause shoulder pain. Direct upward pressure on the shoulder, such as leaning on an elbow, may increase pain.
==Pathophysiology== The literature on the pathophysiology of bursitis describes inflammation as the primary cause of symptoms. Inflammatory bursitis is usually the result of repetitive injury to the bursa. In the subacromial bursa, this generally occurs due to microtrauma to adjacent structures, particularly the supraspinatus tendon. The inflammatory process causes synovial cells to multiply, increasing collagen formation and fluid production within the bursa and reduction in the outside layer of lubrication.<ref>Ishii et al., 1997.</ref>.
Less frequently observed causes of subacromial bursitis include hemorrhagic conditions, crystal deposition and infection.
Many causes have been proposed in the medical literature for subacromial impingement syndrome. The bursa facilitates the motion of the rotator cuff beneath the arch, any disturbance of the relationship of the subacromial structures can lead to impingement. These factors can be broadly classified as intrinsic such as tendon degeneration, rotator cuff muscle weakness and overuse. Extrinsic factors include bone spurs from the [[acromion]] or [[AC joint]], shoulder instability and neurologic problems arising outside of the shoulder.<ref name=Bigliani97/>
==Diagnosis== It is often difficult to distinguish between pain caused by bursitis or that caused by a rotator cuff injury as both exhibit similar pain patterns in the front or side of the shoulder.<ref>Hartley, 1990</ref> Subacromial bursitis can be painful with resisted abduction due to the pinching of the bursa as the deltoid contracts.<ref>Buschbacher & Braddom, 1994.</ref> If the therapist performs a treatment direction test and gently applies joint traction or a caudal glide during abduction (MWM), the painful arc may reduce if the problem is bursitis or adhesive capsulitis (as this potentially increases the subacromial space).
The following clinical tests, if positive, may indicate bursitis: *The patient actively abducts the arm and a painful arc occurs between 80° and 120°. This is due to the compression of the supraspinatus tendon or subacromial bursa between the anterior acromial arch and humeral head. When lowering from full abduction there is often a painful "catch" at midrange. If the patient can achieve adequate muscle relaxation, passive motion tends to be less painful.<ref>Starr & Harbhajan, 2001.</ref> *The patient performs an isometric flexion contraction against resistance of the therapist (Speed’s Test). When the therapist’s resistance is removed, a sudden jerking motion results and latent pain indicates a positive test for bursitis.<ref>Buschbacher & Braddom, 1994.</ref>. *Neer’s Sign: If pain occurs during forward elevation of the internally rotated arm above 90°. This will identify impingement of the rotator cuff but is also sensitive for subacromial bursitis.<ref>Starr & Harbhajan, 2001.</ref>
Irritation or entrapment of the [[lower subscapular nerve]], which innervates the [[subscapularis]] and [[teres major]] muscles, will produce muscle guarding at the shoulder that will restrict motion into external rotation, abduction, or flexion. The aforementioned tests will assist in diagnosing bursitis over other conditions. The diagnosis of impingement syndrome should be viewed with caution in people who are less than forty years old, because such individuals may have subtle glenohumeral instability.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Jobe FW, Kvitne RS, Giangarra CE |title=Shoulder pain in the overhand or throwing athlete. The relationship of anterior instability and rotator cuff impingement |journal=Orthop Rev |volume=18 |issue=9 |pages=963–75 |year=1989 |pmid=2797861 |doi= |url=}}</ref>
===Imaging=== X-rays may help visualize [[bone spur]]s, acromial anatomy and arthritis. Further, [[calcification]] in the subacromial space and rotator cuff may be revealed. [[Osteoarthritis]] of the [[acromioclavicular]] (AC) joint may co-exist and is usually demonstrated on radiographs.
MRI imagining can reveal fluid accumulation in the bursa and assess adjacent structures. In chronic cases caused by impingement tendinosis and tears in the rotator cuff may be revealed. At [[Medical ultrasonography|US]], an abnormal bursa may show # fluid distension, # synovial proliferation, and/or # thickening of the bursal walls.<ref name=":0">Arend CF. Ultrasound of the Shoulder. Master Medical Books, 2013. Free chapter on ultrasound findings of subacromial-subdeltoid bursitis at [http://www.shoulderus.com/ultrasound-of-the-shoulder/ultrasound-subacromial-subdeltoid-bursa/ ShoulderUS.com]</ref> In any case, the magnitude of pathological findings does not correlate with the magnitude of the symptoms.<ref name=":0" />
===Special considerations=== In patients with bursitis who have [[rheumatoid arthritis]], short term improvements are not taken as a sign of resolution and may require long term treatment to ensure recurrence is minimized. Joint contracture of the shoulder has also been found to be at a higher incidence in type two diabetics, which may lead to frozen shoulder (Donatelli, 2004).
==Treatment== Many non-operative treatments have been advocated, including rest; oral administration of [[non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug]]s; [[physical therapy]]; [[chiropractic]]; and local modalities such as [[cryotherapy]], [[ultrasound]], electromagnetic radiation, and subacromial injection of [[corticosteroid]]s.<ref name=Blair96>{{cite journal |vauthors=Blair B, Rokito AS, Cuomo F, Jarolem K, Zuckerman JD |title=Efficacy of injections of corticosteroids for subacromial impingement syndrome |journal=J Bone Joint Surg Am |volume=78 |issue=11 |pages=1685–9 |year=1996 |pmid=8934482 |doi= |url=http://www.ejbjs.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=8934482}}</ref>
Shoulder bursitis rarely requires surgical intervention and generally responds favorably to conservative treatment. Surgery is reserved for patients who fail to respond to non-operative measures. Minimally invasive surgical procedures such as arthroscopic removal of the bursa allows for direct inspection of the shoulder structures and provides the opportunity for removal of bone spurs and repair of any [[rotator cuff tear]]s that may be found.
===Early / initial=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! colspan=3 | Initial phase of physiotherapy rehabilitation |- ! Goals of treatment | colspan=2 valign="top" | * Reduce inflammation * Reduce pain * Prevent weakness and atrophy of muscles as a result of disuse * Increase the patient’s awareness of bursitis * Prevent/reduce impingement and further tissue damage |- ! ! Treatment ! Justification |- ! rowspan=2 valign="top" | Advice and education | valign="top" | Educate the patient about their condition and advise to avoid painful activities and the importance of relative rest of the shoulder | valign="top" | Prevention of pain and impingement which delays the healing process |- | valign="top" | Educate the patient about the importance of correct posture | valign="top" | Puts muscles in the optimal length tension relationship, reducing impingement |- ! rowspan=2 valign="top" | Manual therapy | valign="top" | Grade 1 and 2 accessory mobilisations of the glenohumeral joint | valign="top" | Has a neurophysiological effect reducing pain and improving synovial fluid flow, improving healing |- | valign="top" | Soft tissue massage | valign="top" | Lengthens tight muscles and reduces muscle spasm |- ! rowspan=5 valign="top" | Therapeutic exercise | valign="top" | Gentle pendulum range of motion exercises | valign="top" | Maintenance of range of motion and prevention of adhesive capsulitis |- | valign="top" | Scapular exercises such as shoulder shrugs and shoulder retraction exercises | valign="top" | Improve muscular control and scapular coordination |- | valign="top" | Centering of humeral head | valign="top" | Helps to facilitate adequate muscle timing and recruitment |- | valign="top" | Stretching of tight muscles such as the [[levator scapulae]], [[pectoralis major]], subscapularis and upper [[trapezius muscle]] | valign="top" | To lengthen tight muscles which may improve scapulohumeral rhythm, posture and increase the subacromial space |- | valign="top" | Rotator cuff strengthening - isometric contractions in neutral and 30 degrees abduction | valign="top" | Improves rotator cuff strength which is integral to the stability of the shoulder and functional activities |- ! rowspan=2 valign="top" | Electrophysical modalities | valign="top" | Ice | valign="top" | To reduce inflammation and pain | valign="top" | elevate |- | valign="top" | Low intensity pulsed ultrasound (3 megaHz) | valign="top" | To reduce inflammation and facilitate healing |- ! External physical aids | valign="top" | May use head of humerus repositioning tape | valign="top" | To maintain the head of humerus in its central position for optimal muscle recruitment |}
===Middle / intermittent=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! colspan=3 | Intermittent phase of physiotherapy rehabilitation |- ! Goals of treatment | colspan=2 valign="top" | * Improve muscle control * Improve scapulohumeral rhythm * Improve active and passive range of motion * Restore strength of scapular and rotator cuff muscles |- ! ! Treatment ! Justification |- ! Advice and education | valign="top" | Advise the patient that they must perform all activities and exercises pain free | valign="top" | To prevent reinjury and damage to the bursa |- ! rowspan=3 valign="top" | Manual therapy | valign="top" | Grade 3 and 4 accessory mobilizations of the glenohumeral joint | valign="top" | Improves range of motion and increases synovial fluid movement, improving healing |- | valign="top" | [[Proprioceptive neuromuscular facilitation]] (PNF) in functional diagonal patterns | valign="top" | Strengthens muscles, improves motor control and scapulohumeral rhythm |- | valign="top" | Mobilization with movement e.g. caudal glide with active abduction | valign="top" | Improves range of motion and decreases pain |- ! rowspan=3 valign="top" | Therapeutic exercise | valign="top" | Specific muscle strengthening exercises especially for scapular stabilization (serratus anterior, rhomboids and lower trapezius muscles) e.g. strengthening lower trapezius muscle - bilateral external rotation using a theraband, strengthening of serratus anterior, punching with theraband resistance | valign="top" | Improves stability during scapular motion which may decrease impingement of the bursa in the subacromial space. |- | valign="top" | Active assisted range of motion - creeping the hand up the wall in abduction, scaption and flexion and door pulley manoeuvre | valign="top" | Help to improve active range of motion and gravity assists with shoulder depression |- | valign="top" | Active internal and external rotator exercises with the use of a bar or a theraband | valign="top" | Improves strength of rotator cuff and improves mobility in internal and external rotation |- ! rowspan=2 valign="top" | Electrophysical modalities | valign="top" | Heat | valign="top" | Improves muscle extensibility |- | valign="top" | Low intensity pulsed ultrasound (3 megaHz) | valign="top" | Facilitates healing |- ! External physical aids | valign="top" | May use head of humerus repositioning tape if necessary | valign="top" | To maintain the head of humerus in its optimal position for optimal muscle recruitment |}
===Late / return to function=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! colspan=3 | Return to function phase of physiotherapy rehabilitation |- ! Goals of treatment | colspan=2 valign="top" | * Return the patient to their previous level of function * Achieve full active and passive range of motion |- ! ! Treatment ! Justification |- ! rowspan=3 valign="top" | Education and advice | valign="top" | Education about the importance of a home based exercise program in the late stage of rehabilitation | valign="top" | Ensures patient compliance |- | valign="top" | Correction of techniques performed | valign="top" | Ensures that the correct target muscles are being used |- | valign="top" | Education to ensure that the patient performs activities and exercises within pain free limits | valign="top" | This reduces the chance that the patient may work too hard and cause reinjury |- ! Manual therapy | valign="top" | PNF functional patterns with increasing resistance | valign="top" | Continues to strengthen muscles, improves motor control and scapulohumeral rhythm |- | rowspan=4 valign="top" | '''Therapeutic exercise''' | valign="top" | Exercises specific for the patient’s functional needs e.g. functional reaching | valign="top" | To improve the patients functional ability |- | valign="top" | Proprioception exercises e.g. Wall push ups with the hands resting on medicine balls or dura disks | valign="top" | Improves proprioception important to reduce reinjury as return to function/sport |- | valign="top" | Strengthen the shoulder elevators – deltoid, flexors and also latissimus dorsi. | valign="top" | Important in this phase of the rehabilitation following strengthening of the shoulder depressors |- | valign="top" | Progress strengthening exercises to incorporate speed and load to make more functional | valign="top" | Adding speed and load to exercises ensures that the patient is prepared for more functional tasks and activities |- ! Electrophysical modalities | valign="top" | Ice after exercise | valign="top" | May assist to reduce any inflammation post exercise |- ! External physical aids | valign="top" | May use head of humerus repositioning tape if necessary | valign="top" | May assist with return to function |}
==Prognosis== In 1997 Morrison et al.<ref name=Morrison1997>{{cite journal |vauthors=Morrison DS, Frogameni AD, Woodworth P |title=Non-operative treatment of subacromial impingement syndrome |journal=J Bone Joint Surg Am |volume=79 |issue=5 |pages=732–7 |year=1997 |pmid=9160946 |doi= |url=http://www.ejbjs.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=9160946}}</ref> published a study that reviewed the cases of 616 patients (636 shoulders) with impingement syndrome (painful arc of motion) to assess the outcome of non-surgical care. An attempt was made to exclude patients who were suspected of having additional shoulder conditions such as, full-thickness tears of the rotator cuff, degenerative arthritis of the acromioclavicular joint, instability of the glenohumeral joint, or adhesive capsulitis. All patients were managed with anti-inflammatory medication and a specific, supervised physical-therapy regimen. The patients were followed up from six months to over six years. They found that 67% (413 patients) of the patients improved, while 28% did not improve and went to surgical treatment. 5% did not improve and declined further treatment.
Of the 413 patients who improved, 74 had a recurrence of symptoms during the observation period and their symptoms responded to rest or after resumption of the exercise program.
The Morrison study shows that the outcome of impingement symptoms varies with patient characteristics. Younger patients (20 years or less) and patients between 41 and 60 years of age, fared better than those who were in the 21 to 40 years age group. This may be related to the peak incidence of work, job requirements, sports and hobby related activities, that may place greater demands on the shoulder. However, patients who were older than sixty years of age had the "poorest results". It is known that the rotator cuff and adjacent structures undergo degenerative changes with ageing.
The authors were unable to posit an explanation for the observation of the bimodal distribution of satisfactory results with regard to age. They concluded that it was "unclear why (those) who were twenty-one to forty years old had less satisfactory results". The poorer outcome for patients over 60 years old was thought to be potentially related to "undiagnosed full-thickness tears of the rotator cuff".<ref name=Morrison1997/>

A '''vaccine bath''' is an apparatus used in [[vaccine]] production. As vaccines are very heat labile but inevitably need to be heated to some extent, these devices are used. These are basically [[Heated bath|water baths]], with a temperature set very low. A long time is taken to sterilize vaccines by this method.
Bacterial vaccine are sterilized at 60°C for an hour.
[[Category:Vaccination]]
{{Vaccine-stub}}

{{Infobox Hospital | Name = Walsall Integrated Sexual Health Services | Org/Group = Walsall Healthcare NHS Trust | Image =Walsall Manor Hospital 2.jpg | Caption = Walsall Manor Hospital | Logo = NHS-Logo.svg | Location = [[Walsall]] | Region = [[West Midlands (region)|West Midlands]] | State = | Country = UK || Website = http://www.walsallsexualhealth.co.uk/ |}} '''Walsall Integrated Sexual Health Services''' (WiSH) is a part of the UK [[National Health Service]] that provides sexual healthcare in the [[Walsall]] area of the UK. The services include the treatment and prevention of [[sexually transmitted infection]]s, [[contraception]] and participation in the National Chlamydia Screening Programme.<ref>[https://www.walsallhealthcare.nhs.uk/sexualhealth/home.aspx Walsall Healthcare]</ref> All services are free and confidential and are available to UK and [[European Community]] nationals regardless of age.<ref>[http://www.nhs.uk/chq/Pages/972.aspx?CategoryID=68&SubCategoryID=153 UK NHS]</ref> Since 1 April 2013, Walsall Council (the Local Authority) has been responsible for commissioning the service as part of their public health responsibilities. The funding comes from their allocated public health grant from the UK government.<ref>[https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/144184/Sexual_Health_best_practice_guidance_for_local_authorities_with_IRB.pdf Sexual Health Best Practice Guidance for Local Authorities]</ref>
The service operates from clinics in central Walsall – The Centre for Sexual Health at [[Walsall Manor Hospital]] and WiSH in Navigation Street – and at Willenhall Health Centre, Pinfold Health Centre, Beechdale Health Centre and Darlaston Health Centre. An internet based postal-testing service is also available.<ref>[http://cms.walsall.gov.uk/index/sexualhealth.htm Walsall Sexual Health]</ref>
